misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay linked when one array is sorted
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because names and scores are "conceptually linked", calling Arrays.sort(scores) will also keep the corresponding names aligned with their scores, so they can still use the same index to fetch the top student's name after sorting scores.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray) reorders only the elements of that one int[] array. It does not (and cannot) automatically reorder a separate String[] array to match. Parallel arrays require explicitly swapping both arrays together during sorting, or sorting indices/objects that keep name+score together. After sorting only scores, studentNamesArray remains in original input order, so indices no longer correspond to the same student.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed name may not match the highest score (it prints the last name entered, paired with the highest score after sorting).

evidence.code_snippet:
// I think the names and scores are conceptually linked, so sorting scores
// should also keep the names in the right place logically

String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[indexOfTopStudent];
int topStudentScore = studentScoresArray[indexOfTopStudent];

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Array Sorting Without Index Tracking
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array in a parallel array structure will automatically maintain the correspondence between related elements in other arrays. They think that calling Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray) will somehow magically keep the names aligned with their corresponding scores, even though the names array is never modified.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has a fundamental misunderstanding of how array sorting works. When Arrays.sort() is called on the scores array, it only rearranges the elements within that single array. The names array remains completely untouched and in its original order. The student's mental model fails to account for the fact that parallel arrays require explicit index management—when you sort one array, you must also rearrange the other array using the same index permutations, or track which original indices correspond to which sorted positions. The comment 'the names and scores are conceptually linked, so sorting scores should also keep the names in the right place logically' reveals the student expects the computer to understand this logical relationship and maintain it automatically, which it does not.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: The program will print the student name from the original array position (last index) paired with the highest score from the sorted array (last index), but these will be mismatched. For example, with input Alice(85), Bob(92), Charlie(78), after sorting scores to [78, 85, 92], the program prints studentNamesArray[2]='Charlie' with score 92, producing 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of the correct 'Top student: Bob (92)'.

evidence.code_snippet:
String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[indexOfTopStudent];
            int topStudentScore = studentScoresArray[indexOfTopStudent];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are conceptually linked as parallel arrays, performing a sort operation on one array will automatically reorder the elements in the second array to maintain their relationship.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's memory model, arrays are independent objects. The 'parallel' relationship exists only in the programmer's mind and logic. Standard library methods like Arrays.sort() have no knowledge of external data structures or dependencies; they only manipulate the specific array passed as an argument. To maintain the link, both arrays must be swapped manually in a custom sorting algorithm, or the data should be encapsulated in an Object.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think the names and scores are conceptually linked, so sorting scores
// should also keep the names in the right place logically

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay linked when one array is sorted
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the `names` and `scores` arrays represent related data “conceptually”, sorting the `scores` array will also keep the corresponding `names` in the correct matching order automatically.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, two separate arrays have no built-in relationship. `Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray)` only reorders the elements inside the `studentScoresArray`. The `studentNamesArray` remains in its original order, so the index-based pairing (parallel array relationship) is broken unless you swap/move elements in both arrays together (or use objects like a `Student` class and sort a single array/list of Students).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed top student name may not correspond to the highest score after sorting (name/score mismatch).

evidence.code_snippet:
// I think the names and scores are conceptually linked, so sorting scores
// should also keep the names in the right place logically

String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[indexOfTopStudent];
int topStudentScore = studentScoresArray[indexOfTopStudent];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the names and scores arrays are 'conceptually linked' (they represent related student data), sorting one array will somehow keep the other array synchronized with the correct corresponding values. They think the logical relationship between the arrays guarantees automatic correspondence after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Arrays in Java are completely independent data structures. When you call Arrays.sort() on one array, it only modifies that specific array. Other arrays are not automatically reordered to maintain correspondence. To keep parallel arrays synchronized, you must manually swap or reorder elements in ALL arrays together during any sorting operation. The conceptual link exists only in the programmer's mind, not in Java's execution model.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program produces 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)' because the scores were sorted to [78, 85, 92] while names remained ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"], breaking the name-score correspondence.

evidence.code_snippet:
// I think the names and scores are conceptually linked, so sorting scores
// should also keep the names in the right place logically

String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[indexOfTopStudent];
int topStudentScore = studentScoresArray[indexOfTopStudent];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are conceptually linked as parallel arrays, performing a sorting operation on one array will automatically reorder the elements of the other array to maintain the correspondence between indices.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory. The Arrays.sort() method only receives a reference to a single array and reorders its elements. It has no mechanism to observe, link to, or synchronize changes with other arrays, even if the programmer intends for them to be parallel.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think the names and scores are conceptually linked, so sorting scores
// should also keep the names in the right place logically
